I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  During the country programming mission in December 2009, the government of the 
People's Republic of China (PRC) requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide 
capacity development technical assistance (TA) to help the Tianjin municipal government (TMG) 
promote  energy  conservation  in  Tianjin.  The  TA  was  included  in  ADB's  2010  non-lending 
pipeline for the PRC.1 The concept paper was approved on 10 June 2010 and the fact-finding 
mission was fielded from 10–13 August 2010, during which an agreement was reached with the 
Government of the PRC on the TA’s impact, outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, 
and financing plan. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Tianjin is located 137 kilometers southeast of Beijing. It is one of four municipalities in 
the PRC that have provincial status, reporting directly to the central government. 2 Like many 
provinces and municipalities in the PRC, Tianjin has experienced rapid economic growth over 
the  past  two  decades.  In  2009,  its  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  grew  by  16.5%  to 
CNY750 billion ($112 billion) compared with 2008—the second-fastest growth among all PRC 
provinces.3 Its GDP per capita reached CNY62,403 ($9,328), the third highest of the provinces.4 
The robust growth despite the global financial crisis was mainly attributable to the municipality's 
huge investment on fixed assets, which in 2009 reached CNY500.6 billion ($74.8 billion), a 
47.1% surge over the previous year and a record high in the past 18 years.  
 
3.  Tianjin's economic growth is largely propelled by the Binhai district, officially known as 
Binhai New Area, which is a major economic development zone within the jurisdiction of Tianjin 
municipality.  Binhai  New  Area  is  considered  the  strongest  and  most  dynamic  economic 
development in the Bohai Rim region5 of Northern China, and is expected to emulate the 
success in the special economic development zones of Shenzhen in Guangdong and Pudong in 
Shanghai. In 2009, Binhai New Area's GDP reached CNY381 billion ($57 billion) and accounted 
for about 50% of Tianjin's GDP.  
 
4.  Tianjin's economic development has been energy intensive. Total energy consumption in 
2008 was 53.6 million tons of coal equivalent (tce)—up 8.5% from 49.4 million tce in 2007. But 
energy intensity has dropped gradually as Tianjin adjusted its industry structure and phased out 
old production facilities.6 In 2008, Tianjin's energy intensity was 0.95 tce per CNY10,000 GDP, 
down  6.8%  from  1.02  tce  in  2007.  This  is  about  13.8%  lower  than  the  national  average 
(1.102 tce in 2008). Tianjin ranked 8th among 30 provinces and municipalities.7 Sulfur dioxide 
(SO ) emission was also reduced, from 244,700 tons in 2007 to 240,100 tons in 2008, and 
2
chemical oxygen demand (COD) fell from 137,300 tons to 133,100 tons. In 2009, energy

5.  Major industries operating in Tianjin are petrochemicals, machinery, car manufacturing, 
electronics,  mechanical  industries,  and  textile.  Tianjin's  rapid  industrial  development  and 
urbanization, if left unmanaged, could result in energy supply problems, severe air and water 
pollution, and environmental degradation that could badly affect its 11.8 million population. TMG 
recognizes that the municipality's present growth trajectory for energy and related emissions is 
unsustainable and has initiated plans toward energy conservation. Tianjin’s target is aligned 
with the national target, which is to achieve energy intensity reduction of 20% per unit of GDP 
by 2010, and emission intensity reduction of 40-45% per unit of GDP by 2020, taking 2005 as 
the baseline. Considering Tianjin’s heavy-industry-based economic structure, these are huge 
challenges for TMG. 
 
6.  To overcome these challenges, TMG has developed an overall action plan that includes 
conserving energy, optimizing the industry structure, phasing out old production lines, and 
diversifying the energy mix. TMG is aware of the enormous potential for energy conservation8 
and the benefits it can provide not only by bolstering energy supply security but in reducing 
energy resource use, associated financing needs, and emissions. TMG has set forth its energy 
conservation  plan  focused  on  six  energy-intensive  industries  (metallurgy,  petrochemical, 
construction, transportation, power generation, and machinery). TMG recognizes that meeting 
energy  intensity  and  emission  reduction  targets  needs  more  concerted  efforts.  A  vigorous 
energy conservation drive will be its next strategy for achieving its goal of sustainable economic 
and social development. 
 
7.  TMG's goal is to achieve a sustainable mechanism for promoting energy conservation 
technologies and providing suitable financing. However, there is an urgent need to rationalize 
the  various  energy  conservation  technologies  available  and  customize  them  for  energy-
intensive industrial sectors. TMG needs support in the following areas: (i) acquiring knowledge 
on  international  and  national  best-practice  technologies  for  energy  conservation  in  these 
industries  and  their  processes;  (ii)  performing  energy  audits  and  establishing  an  energy 
conservation platform (ECP) that will develop a database integrating both supply and demand 
data, and provide guidance on the technologies best suited to these industries; (iii) identifying 
and designing suitable financing instruments for required investments; (iv) promoting energy 
conservation awareness among industrial enterprises; and (v) developing capacity. TMG is 
seeking  ADB  assistance  to  analyze  these  issues,  and  develop  a  systematic  energy 
conservation mechanism and comprehensive ECP that can serve the growing needs of the 
municipality and its neighboring areas in the Bohai Rim region. The TA can provide a potent tool 
for TMG and the industry participants to determine and realize the large potential for energy 
conservation  by  selecting  the  most  suitable  technologies,  matching  them  with  innovative 
financing tools and financing sources, and monitoring and verifying them through a best-practice 
regulatory regime.9 
 
                                                 
8  TMG has established its energy conservation service capability through the Tianjin Science and Technology 
Commission. In 2008, it created four service teams for the chemical and metallurgy industries, industry boilers, and 
district heating. In 2009, it added service teams for light emitting diode lighting, gas-fueled vehicles, water resource 
protection, and building energy efficiency. 
9  An  Energy  Conservation  Ordinance,  issued  in  2001,  requires  enterprises  and  businesses  to  adopt  energy 
conservation measures and meet national energy consumption targets. TMG has since issued several supporting 
ordinances.

3
8.  ADB's Long-Term Strategic Framework 2008–2020 (Strategy 2020)10 made achieving 
environmental sustainability a priority, with energy as a core operational sector. New initiatives 
(e.g. Clean Energy Financing Partnership Facility) have been introduced to augment ADB 
assistance  to  developing  member  countries  for  acquiring  low-carbon  technologies  and 
implementing energy efficiency projects. ADB’s country partnership strategy for the PRC11 also 
emphasized balanced and sustainable growth with more efficient use of resources and more 
stringent protection of the environment. One of the key priorities of the 11th Five-Year Plan of 
the PRC is to improve energy efficiency by 20%, making it a flagship program to address 
climate change and environmental challenges arising from rapid economic growth. The TA has 
a close fit with both ADB's and the PRC's priorities. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
   
9.  The impact of the TA will be greater energy conservation and emission reduction in 
Tianjin municipality. The outcome of the TA will be stronger capacity to plan and implement 
energy conservation and emission reduction projects in Tianjin. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
10.  The outputs of the TA will be (i) review and analysis of international and national proven 
energy conservation technologies, and their possible applications in selected energy-intensive 
industries; (ii) development of a strategy and action plan to implement energy conservation 
through the ECP; (iii) establishment of an ECP and its implementation; (iv) priority selection of 
energy conservation projects; and (v) capacity development and information dissemination. 
 
11.  The TA components are described below:  
 
(i)  Review and analysis. This will (a) investigate nationally proven technologies 
and practices, and prepare comparative analysis with international best practice; 
(b) develop an inventory of establishments and the technologies that can be 
applied in six selected industries in Tianjin or the Bohai Rim region; (c) compare 
and identify the potential for energy conservation through technology upgrades; 
(d) examine the incentive or regulatory structure in place to promote energy 
conservation in these industries, compare them with international best practices 
and define the gaps, if any; and (e) analyze the financing needs and develop an 
investment  plan  for  energy  conservation  in  the  selected  industries.  For  the 
industries located in Tianjin, consultants will use the information and data to be 
provided by the executing agency and supplement them with findings from a 
survey conducted as part of the TA. The survey will cover about 100 companies 
in the six selected industries and obtain specific data on the technologies now 
employed for various processes, the related energy consumption and emission 
data, energy conservation practices, etc.   
 
(ii)  Strategy  and  action  plan.  Based  on  the  above  data  and  its  analysis,  this 
component will develop a strategy and recommend an action plan to promote 
energy conservation through the ECP. It will determine how the activities that

(iii)  Establishment  of  an  ECP. This will be the main output of the TA and will 
integrate the analysis and recommendations described in components (i) and (ii). 
The consultants’ work will include (a) developing the website and establishing 
links with international networks, and selected cities and provinces within the 
Bohai  Rim  region;  (b)  setting  up  the  database  to  integrate  the  output  of 
component (i) and data obtained through the survey, including energy saving 
information,  technologies,  experts,  available  resources,  opportunities; 
(c) identifying sources of funding for possible energy conservation projects; and 
(d) developing a user manual for the operation of the ECP. The consultants will 
purchase the necessary software or engage information technology services to 
help perform these tasks. 
  
(iv)  Priority  selection  of  energy  conservation  projects. This will consider the 
replication  potential  of  the  type  of  energy  conservation  measures  that  are 
selected upfront for demonstrating the ECP. It will also (a) provide a set of criteria 
for  selecting  priority  projects,  including  technical  considerations,  investment 
requirements, financing arrangement, and implementation schedules; and (b) 
define  critical  issues  to  be  addressed,  steps  to  be  taken  by  the  TMG,  and 
assistance required to develop the proposed projects. 
 
(v)  Capacity development and information dissemination.  This component will 
(a) train the executing and implementing agencies on the operation, maintenance 
and upgrade of the ECP; (b) develop a public dissemination strategy to promote 
the use of the ECP by various industries and share the TA outputs with other 
municipalities  and  provinces;  and  (c)  conduct  a  consultation  workshop  with 
stakeholders,  an  international  field  study  program  for  selected  staff  of  the 
executing and implementing agencies, and the final workshop to disseminate the 
TA outputs. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $600,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on 
a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). It is proposed 
that ADB provide $400,000 equivalent on a grant basis from TASF-others. The Government will 
finance the remaining $200,000 equivalent through in-kind contributions, including providing 
data and other information needed for the TA, counterpart staff, office accommodations and 
facilities, and transportation for site visits as required. The cost estimates and financing plan is 
in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  The Tianjin Science and Technology Commission (TSTC) will be the executing agency 
and  responsible  for  overall  TA  management  and  supervision.  Tianjin  Intertech  Consulting 
Company,  a  non-profit  energy  consulting  organization  co-owned  by  TSTC,  will  be  the 
implementing agency. It will select the consultants, oversee the day-to-day implementation of

5
the TA activities, and provide logistic support to the consultants. TSTC will own and manage the 
future  operations  of  the  ECP.  This  TA  will  be  carried  out  as  a  delegated  TA  under  the 
agreement of ADB and the Ministry of Finance.12 Consultants will be hired based on procedures 
required  by  ADB  and  in  close  cooperation  with  ADB’s  Central  Operations  Services  Office 
(COSO). For this purpose, a capacity assessment was undertaken jointly with COSO during the 
fact-finding mission and a separate report was prepared. ADB will be responsible for signing the 
contract with the consultants, while the executing agency will be responsible for supervising the 
consultants’ work. The executing agency will provide counterpart staff, office accommodation 
and facilities, and transportation for site visits, as required. Likewise, TSTC will make available 
data and other information needed for the TA as well as guidance on the design of the system 
infrastructure for the proposed ECP. 
 
14.  The TA will require a total of 5.0 person-months of international and 14 person-months 
of national consulting services. The outline terms of reference are in Appendix 3. As a delegated 
TA, the experts will be selected by the executing agency through a consulting firm using biodata 
technical proposal procedures based on the quality- and cost-based selection method (quality–
cost ratio of 80:20) and in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (April 
2010, as amended from time to time). Survey and system development services will be part of 
the consultants’ contracts. Procurement of equipment, supplies, and materials by consultants 
under the TA will follow ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (April 2010, as amended from time to 
time). Equipment purchased under the TA will be turned over to the executing agency after 
completion of the TA. The executing agency, with inputs from the consultants, will finalize scope 
and content of the training and information dissemination programs. Financial arrangements for 
training,  workshops,  survey  and  system  development  services  will  be  included  in  the 
consultants’ contracts. Disbursements under the TA will be done in accordance with ADB's 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (May 2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
15.  The TA will be implemented over 15 months beginning in March 2011, with an expected 
completion date of June 2012. The consultants will submit—an inception report within 1 month; 
survey reports within 5 and 8 months; interim reports within 6 and 9 months; an information 
technology report within 12 months; a draft final report within 13 months; and the final report 
within 15 months of the TA start date. Information on the progress of implementation and on TA 
outputs will be disseminated through regular communications with the executing agency and 
scheduled  workshops.  Knowledge  dissemination  through  workshops  with  participation  from 
selected industries, energy service companies and government officials will be organized. At the 
end of the TA, an ECP will have been developed and made operational, and the related output 
reports and TA activities will be completed. The outcome of the TA will be subject to evaluation 
by both ADB and the government in accordance with their respective evaluation policies and 
requirements. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the People’s Republic of China for Promoting Energy Conservation in Tianjin, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board. 
                                                 
12 A memorandum of understanding on Enhanced Partnership on Technical Assistance Delegation to the Executing 
Agency between ADB and the Ministry of Finance was signed in November 2009.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The capacity development technical assistance (TA) will be implemented in consultation 
with relevant stakeholders led by the Tianjin Science and Technology Commission (TSTC), the 
executing  agency,  and  Tianjin  Intertech  Consulting  Company,  the  implementing  agency. 
International and national specialists will be selected by the executing and/or implementing 
agencies and engaged by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) through a consulting firm using 
biodata technical proposal procedures and quality- and cost-based selection method (quality–
cost ratio of 80:20) and in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (April 
2010, as amended from time to time). The consultants will have extensive knowledge of energy 
conservation issues in the People’s Republic of China (PRC). Services of two international 
consultants and four national consultants will be engaged. The international consultants will 
ensure quality and timely delivery of required outputs, provide guidance and leadership to, and 
coordinate requirements from, the national consultants. The national consultants will assist the 
international consultants in producing the outputs reports, provide and review specific inputs 
and analytical data, develop recommendations, and translate relevant documents into English. 
 
A.  International and National Consultants 
 
3.  Energy Conservation Specialist and Team Leader (3 person-months, international; 
5 person-months, national). The specialists shall have an engineering background and strong 
report-writing skills. The international consultant will act as team leader of the consulting team 
and be responsible for all coordination activities, provide oversight, lead the preparation, and 
ensure quality and timely delivery of TA outputs. The national consultant will act as co-team 
leader and will be responsible for the coordination activities among the national consultants, 
executing and implementing agencies, and other stakeholders, and act as resource person 
during the workshops. The tasks of the specialists will include, but will not be limited to: 
(i)  Collect and review information available in the public domain, previous ADB 
studies, data provided by the executing and implementing agencies, and those 
obtained through the survey to be conducted under the TA; 
(ii)  Review  the  targets  under  the  12th  Five-Year  Plan,  Tianjin  municipality,  and 
disaggregated targets of different industries for promoting energy conservation, 
improving energy efficiency and reducing emissions;  
(iii)  In consultation with the executing and implementing agencies, review energy 
consumption, energy-consuming processes, energy conservation practices, etc. 
in the selected energy-intensive industries; specify investigation methods for the 
survey and prepare an investigation plan; formulate a survey questionnaire; 
(iv)  Finalize  the  terms  of  reference  for  the  survey  services  and  the  information 
technology and database management developer;  
(v)  Review and analyze survey results and provide guidance and quality checks for 
the development of the energy conservation platform (ECP); 
(vi)  Review  international  best  practices  for  the  selected  industries,  considering 
national  and  industrial  differences  in  regulatory  mechanisms,  and  determine 
applicable practices and technologies for Tianjin; 
(vii)  Analyze the selected industries, review their production technologies, energy 
consumption  patterns  and  energy  efficiency,  and  compare  them  with 
corresponding international and national energy efficiency benchmarks; 
(viii)  Pinpoint opportunities for energy conservation/efficiency; estimate the potential 
for saving energy in the selected industries based on investigation results;

Appendix 3  11 
(ix)  Identify major carbon dioxide (CO ) emission sources in the selected energy-
2
intensive industries; estimate the potential to reduce CO  emissions from the 
2
selected industries; 
(x)  Review existing structural, policy, regulatory, organizational, and financing setups 
of the selected industries, and identify major regulatory, technical, financial and 
institutional barriers to energy conservation; 
(xi)  Recommend a strategy and action plan to promote energy conservation and to 
implement the ECP in Tianjin; recommend implementing mechanisms and a 
time-bound  action  plan;  recommend  how  the ECP  can  gain  wider  coverage 
geographically and across industries for a bigger impact; evaluate the replication 
potential of the type of energy conservation measures that are selected upfront 
for demonstrating the ECP; 
(xii)  Help organize a study tour for selected staff of the executing and implementing 
agencies through (a) selecting, and coordinating with, resource organizations; 
and (b) providing guidance in documenting the findings of the study tour; 
(xiii)  Develop a public information and dissemination strategy; 
(xiv)  Organize the workshops with stakeholders and act as resource person. 
   
4.  Energy  Efficiency  Specialist  (2  person-months,  international;  2.5  person-months, 
national). The specialists shall have an engineering background and strong report-writing skills. 
The specialists will be primarily responsible for producing the outputs in component 4 and will 
coordinate all formulation work with the team leader. They will also provide support to the team 
leader for components 1 and 2. The tasks of the specialists will include, but will not be limited to: 
(i)  Review the Government’s and TMG’s policies and targets to promote energy 
conservation; identify government policies and regulations that will be required to 
provide adequate incentives for adopting energy conservation in the selected 
industries;  assess  options  and  recommend  a  set  of  policies  that  would  be 
necessary to develop and implement energy conservation and efficiency projects 
in Tianjin; 
(ii)  Analyze situation in Tianjin, summarize the barriers, and identify opportunities 
and potentials for the development of energy conservation services and other 
technological support systems; 
(iii)  Review the energy efficiency project models in Guangdong and Shandong, and 
international efforts to improve energy conservation and efficiency, and assess 
their potential for replication in Tianjin; 
(iv)  Review the results of the survey conducted for Tianjin and specify priority areas; 
(v)  Propose new measures and develop suitable approaches to promoting energy 
conservation and efficiency, including development of energy service companies 
that can target energy efficiency improvements in the selected industries; 
(vi)  Evaluate the replication potential of the type of energy conservation measures 
that are selected upfront for demonstrating the ECP, and recommend a strategy 
and action plan for wider acceptance and implementation; 
(vii)  Select  and  prioritize  possible  energy  efficiency  projects  and  recommend 
applicable project design, financing options, and implementation arrangements to 
reflect the complexity and diversity of the prospective projects in Tianjin; 
(viii)  Present a cost-benefit analysis, and highlight energy savings and other benefits 
(e.g., environmental benefits and emission reduction) of the proposed projects (in 
coordination with the energy economist and finance specialist); 
(ix)  Recommend eligibility criteria and screening procedure for prospective projects.

12  Appendix 3 
 
5.  Energy  Economist  and  Finance  Specialist  (2.5  person-months,  national).  The 
specialist shall have a background in economics and finance, and experience in undertaking 
economic and financial analyses of investment project proposals. The tasks will include: 
(i)  Provide general macro and sector information such as energy production and 
consumption  by  sectors,  energy  efficiency,  and  electricity  production  and 
consumption  by  sectors  (current  and  historical)  for  the  PRC  and  Tianjin 
municipality; analyze the information to provide an overview of the sector for the 
PRC and Tianjin municipality.  
(ii)  Based on data that can be provided through the survey, develop an estimate, in 
terms of economic costs and benefits, of promoting energy conservation and 
efficiency; 
(iii)  Recommend options for implementing energy conservation projects in Tianjin, 
evaluate the resources needed and assess the economic benefits; 
(iv)  Consult  with  other  experts  in  determining  and  prioritizing  possible  energy 
efficiency projects, and recommend applicable project design, financing options, 
and implementation arrangements to reflect the complexity and diversity of the 
prospective projects in Tianjin; 
(v)  Present a cost-benefit analysis, and highlight energy savings and other financial 
and economic benefits of prospective projects; 
(vi)  Assist in developing eligibility criteria and screening procedure for prospective 
projects. 
 
6.  Information Technology and Database Management Specialist (4 person-months, 
national). The specialist shall (i) be a graduate of computer science or a related field; (ii) have 
extensive experience in the design and development of database management and information 
systems; and (iii) possess sufficient knowledge and practical experience of the operations, 
management, and infrastructure of an energy conservation platform. The tasks of the specialist 
will include, but will not be limited to:  
(i)  Provide technical and advisory guidance in the development of the ECP through 
the  establishment  of  a  website  and  use  of  the  database  system,  including 
development and use of applicable approaches to access services that help 
identify  relevant  information  in  national  sites  and  other  energy  conservation 
information services; 
(ii)  Review the readiness status and the requirements for deploying the proposed 
ECP;  determine  key  issues  (e.g.,  organizational  support,  availability  of  staff, 
technical know-how, and resources to manage and maintain the ECP); develop a 
guidance note listing the requirements for establishing and operating the ECP; 
(iii)  Assess  the  quality  of  the  current  database,  assist  in  specifying  additional 
information needed, and together with the executing and implementing agencies, 
identify entities between which data flows; 
(iv)  Provide inputs for the survey questionnaire as appropriate; 
(v)  As necessary and in consultation with the executing and implementing agencies, 
finalize the terms of reference for the software and system developer; 
(vi)  Hold meetings with the executing and implementing agencies, other stakeholders 
and the system developer to establish the specific requirements of the system;  
(vii)  Provide guidance for the design of the database format and, if necessary, the 
design of the data center and web server; review quality control measures in 
inputting data into the database; 
(viii)  Review specifications for hardware and software requirements; 
(ix)  Review  guidelines  for  operating  and  updating  the  ECP;  recommend  a 
management structure and partnership arrangements among stakeholders;

Appendix 3  13 
(x)  Assess initial operation of the database and the need for corrective actions; 
(xi)  Recommend  feasible  financing  and  revenue-generating  options  for  the 
sustainable operation of the ECP; 
(xii)  Design a training program for the operation, maintenance and upgrade of the 
ECP, and act as resource person during the workshops. 
 
7.  Draft  Terms  of  Reference  for  the  Survey  Services.  A  survey  covering  about 
100 companies in the selected industries will be undertaken to collect basic information on 
energy use, major equipment used, capacities and energy consumption and/or performance of 
this equipment, emissions (CO , sulfur dioxide, greenhouse gas, carbon oxygen demand, etc.), 
2
technologies now applied, energy conservation practices and potential areas for improvement, 
etc. The companies to be surveyed shall be determined by the executing agency, which will also 
organize an expert team to validate the survey results. The data obtained from the survey will 
supplement the data already assembled by the executing agency, and will form the initial 
database of the ECP. The survey team shall work closely with the team leader in the design of 
the survey plan, content, and output. The survey team shall have undertaken at least three 
survey projects in the past. The tasks will include, but will not be limited to: 
(i)  In consultation with the executing agency and the team leader, design a survey 
plan, data collection form, and questionnaire; together with the executing agency, 
prepare a list of the companies to be surveyed and determine their total share in 
the  industrial  sector  of  Tianjin  (both  by  gross  domestic  product  and  energy 
consumption); 
(ii)  Collect and analyze data from at least 100 companies; where appropriate, obtain 
the energy consumption per unit of main output of each process, and identify 
energy-consuming processes; 
(iii)  Benchmark and compare a process energy consumption index with industry 
standards for the PRC and worldwide; 
(iv)  Work with the national team leader/energy efficiency specialist to determine the 
main  opportunities  for  the  companies  to improve  their  energy  efficiency  and 
emission reduction; point out companies in each industry that have high energy 
conservation potential; 
(v)  Point out potential projects where implementation of energy conservation and 
efficiency measures can be demonstrated;  
(vi)  Assist  the  information  technology  team  in  providing  required  inputs  for  the 
development of the ECP database; 
(vii)  Prepare a survey report. 
 
8.  Draft Terms of Reference for the Information Technology System Developer. The 
IT system developer shall be familiar with the government system requirements, and with 
products and solutions of mainstream network manufacturers. Staff to be assigned are expected 
to (a) be graduates of computer science or a related field; (b) have extensive experience in the 
design and development of database management and information systems; (c) have sufficient 
knowledge and practical experience of the operations, management, and infrastructure of an 
energy conservation platform; (d) have the capability of using database to analyze business 
information requirements and risks; (e) be proficient in JAVA Web Developer, Oracle, MySql, 
DB2 and other web server configuration; (f) have sufficient experience in large-scale systems 
architecture; (g) be proficient in the major routing exchange technology network protocol; and (i) 
be able to perform analysis of the network obstacles, and deal with network problems that may 
arise in a time-efficient manner. The tasks of the system developer will include, but will not be 
limited to:

14  Appendix 3 
 
(i)  Hold meetings with the executing and implementing agencies, and the IT and 
database management specialist to specify the requirements for establishing a 
data center and web server; 
(ii)  With guidance from these agencies and the specialist, formulate a management 
structure and partnership arrangements among stakeholders for operation and 
maintenance of the data center and web server; integrate features specified by 
the agencies into the design of the ECP; 
(iii)  Determine the hardware, software, and training requirements for the system; 
develop specifications for hardware and software for the database, data center 
and web server; 
(iv)  Purchase software and/or create a user-friendly web application to aggregate 
information  on  energy  conservation  and  efficiency  statistics,  practices, 
technologies, and opportunities for key energy-intensive industries, and establish 
a data center and web server; 
(v)  Identify necessary actions for the maintenance and efficient functioning of the 
system, and determine cost-effective options for sustainability; 
(vi)  Advise  on  practical  solutions  for  computer  networking  within  the  Bohai  Rim 
region and with international alliances;  
(vii)  Develop a user manual; 
(viii)  Act as resource person in workshops and conferences. 
 
B.   Deliverables. All required reports should be submitted in both English and Chinese with 
copies for the executing and implementing agencies, and ADB. The expected deliverables of 
the consulting services shall include: 
(i)  Inception  report.  To  be  submitted  within  2  months  after  the  TA  starts, 
summarizing the initial findings, suggesting changes needed (if any) in the TA's 
approach, methodology, and time schedule. 
(ii)  Interim reports. To be submitted within 6 and 9 months after the TA starts, as 
indicated in the Design and Monitoring Framework’s Activities with Milestones. 
(iii)  Survey reports. To be submitted within 5 months (interim report) and 8 months 
(final survey report) after the TA starts. 
(iv)  Consultation workshop. The workshop will be held within 8 months after the TA 
starts  to  (a)  present  to  the  stakeholders  the  initial  TA  findings  and 
recommendations; (b) promote exchange of ideas and collect comments; and 
(c) boost ownership of and commitment to the TA recommendations. 
(v)  IT report. To be submitted within 12 months after the TA starts. 
(vi)  Draft final report. To be submitted within 13 months after the TA starts. The 
draft final report (DFR) will include all components required in the study and 
cover all aspects of the TA implementation. 
(vii)  Final workshop. The workshop will be held within 1 month after the submission 
of  the  DFR  (within  14  months  after  the  TA  starts)  to  (a)  present  to  the 
stakeholders  the  overall  TA  findings  and  recommendations,  and  gather 
comments on the DFR; and (b) disseminate the ECP.  
(viii)  Final report. To be submitted within 1 month after the final workshop (15 months 
after the TA starts). The consultants will incorporate the comments from the 
stakeholders in the final report. An executive summary and a knowledge product 
will also be submitted.
